<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-The_Beatles skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">The Beatles</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><div class="dablink">"Fab Four" redirects here. For other uses, see <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">The Beatles (disambiguation)</a>&#32;and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fab_Four_(disambiguation)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fab Four (disambiguation) (page does not exist)">Fab Four (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_British_(Oxford)_English&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use British (Oxford) English (page does not exist)">Template:Use British (Oxford) English</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_dmy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use dmy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use dmy dates</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_musical_artist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Infobox musical artist (page does not exist)">Template:Infobox musical artist</a>
</p><p><b>The Beatles</b> were an English <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock</a> band that formed in <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>, in 1960. With <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon" title="John Lennon">John Lennon</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Paul_McCartney&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Paul McCartney (page does not exist)">Paul McCartney</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison" title="George Harrison">George Harrison</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ringo_Starr" title="Ringo Starr">Ringo Starr</a>, they became widely regarded as the greatest and most influential act of the rock era.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup>  Rooted in <a href="/wiki/Skiffle" title="Skiffle">skiffle</a> and 1950s <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">rock and roll</a>, the Beatles later experimented with several <a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_genre&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music genre (page does not exist)">genres</a>, ranging from <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> <a href="/wiki/Ballad" title="Ballad">ballads</a> to <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_rock" title="Psychedelic rock">psychedelic rock</a>, often incorporating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Classical_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Classical music (page does not exist)">classical</a> elements in innovative ways. In the early 1960s, their enormous popularity first emerged as "<a href="/wiki/Beatlemania" title="Beatlemania">Beatlemania</a>", but as their songwriting grew in sophistication they came to be perceived as an embodiment of the ideals shared by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Counterculture_of_the_1960s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Counterculture of the 1960s (page does not exist)">era's sociocultural revolutions</a>.
</p><p>Starting in 1960, the Beatles built their reputation playing clubs in Liverpool and <a href="/wiki/Hamburg" title="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> over a three-year period. Manager <a href="/wiki/Brian_Epstein" title="Brian Epstein">Brian Epstein</a> moulded them into a professional act and producer <a href="/wiki/George_Martin" title="George Martin">George Martin</a> enhanced their musical potential. They gained popularity in the United Kingdom after their first hit, "<a href="/wiki/Love_Me_Do" title="Love Me Do">Love Me Do</a>", in late 1962. They acquired the nickname the "Fab Four" as Beatlemania grew in Britain over the following year, and by early 1964 they had become international stars, leading the "<a href="/wiki/British_Invasion" title="British Invasion">British Invasion</a>" of the United States pop market. From 1965 on, the Beatles produced what many critics consider their finest material, including the innovative and widely influential albums <i><a href="/wiki/Rubber_Soul" title="Rubber Soul">Rubber Soul</a></i> (1965), <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Revolver_(The_Beatles_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Revolver (The Beatles album) (page does not exist)">Revolver</a></i> (1966), <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i> (1967), <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)">The Beatles (White Album)</a></i> (1968), and <i><a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road" title="Abbey Road">Abbey Road</a></i> (1969). After their <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_break-up&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles' break-up (page does not exist)">break-up</a> in 1970, they each enjoyed successful musical careers. Lennon was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Death_of_John_Lennon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Death of John Lennon (page does not exist)">shot and killed</a> in December 1980, and Harrison died of lung cancer in November 2001. McCartney and Starr, the remaining members, remain musically active.
</p><p>According to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">RIAA</a>, the Beatles are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists_in_the_United_States" title="List of best-selling music artists in the United States">best-selling band in the United States</a>, with 177 million certified units. They have had more number-one albums on the British charts and sold more singles in the UK than any other act. In 2008, the group topped <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_(magazine)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard (magazine) (page does not exist)">Billboard</a></i> magazine's list of the all time most successful "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Billboard_Hot_100_All-Time_Top_Artists&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Billboard Hot 100 All-Time Top Artists (page does not exist)">Hot 100</a>" artists; as of 2014, they hold the record for <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_best-charting_music_artists_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of best-charting music artists in the United States (page does not exist)">most number-one hits on the Hot 100</a> chart with 20. They have received ten <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Award" title="Grammy Award">Grammy Awards</a>, an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award (page does not exist)">Academy Award</a> for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score#1970s" title="Academy Award for Best Original Score">Best Original Score</a> and fifteen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ivor_Novello_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ivor Novello Awards (page does not exist)">Ivor Novello Awards</a>. Collectively included in <i><a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)">Time</a></i> magazine's compilation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_100:_The_Most_Important_People_of_the_Century&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century (page does not exist)">the 20th century's 100 most influential people</a>, they are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling band</a> in history, with <a href="/wiki/EMI_Records" title="EMI Records">EMI Records</a> estimating sales of over one billion units. In 2004, <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> ranked the Beatles as the greatest artist of all time.
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id=".7B.7B.23invoke:anchor.7Cmain.7D.7D_1957.E2.80.9362:_formation.2C_Hamburg.2C_and_UK_popularity">{{#invoke:anchor|main}} 1957–62: formation, Hamburg, and UK popularity</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:The_Beatles_history&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:The Beatles history (page does not exist)">Template:The Beatles history</a>
</p><p>In March 1957, John Lennon, then aged sixteen, formed a skiffle group with several friends from Quarry Bank school. They briefly called themselves the Blackjacks, before changing their name to <a href="/wiki/The_Quarrymen" title="The Quarrymen">the Quarrymen</a> after discovering that a respected local group was already using the other name.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Fifteen-year-old Paul McCartney joined as a rhythm guitarist shortly after he and Lennon met that July.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In February 1958, McCartney invited his friend George Harrison to watch the band. The fourteen-year-old auditioned for Lennon, impressing him with his playing, but Lennon initially thought Harrison was too young to join. After a month of Harrison's persistence, they enlisted him as their lead guitarist.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> By January 1959, Lennon's Quarry Bank friends had left the group, and he began studies at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liverpool_College_of_Art&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liverpool College of Art (page does not exist)">Liverpool College of Art</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The three guitarists, billing themselves at least three times as Johnny and the Moondogs,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> were playing rock and roll whenever they could find a drummer.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon's art school friend <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Sutcliffe" title="Stuart Sutcliffe">Stuart Sutcliffe</a>, who had recently sold one of his paintings and purchased a bass guitar, joined in January 1960, and it was he who suggested changing the band's name to Beatals as a tribute to <a href="/wiki/Buddy_Holly" title="Buddy Holly">Buddy Holly</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Crickets" title="The Crickets">the Crickets</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They used the name through May, when they became the Silver Beetles, before undertaking a brief tour of Scotland as the backing group for pop singer and fellow Liverpudlian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johnny_Gentle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johnny Gentle (page does not exist)">Johnny Gentle</a>. By early July, they changed their name to the Silver Beatles and by the middle of August to the Beatles.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Allan_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allan Williams (page does not exist)">Allan Williams</a>, the Beatles' unofficial manager, arranged a resident band booking for them in Hamburg, but lacking a full-time drummer they auditioned and hired <a href="/wiki/Pete_Best" title="Pete Best">Pete Best</a> in mid-August. The band, now a five-piece, left four days later, contracted to club owner <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bruno_Koschmider&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bruno Koschmider (page does not exist)">Bruno Koschmider</a> for what would be a 3½-month residency.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Beatles' historian Mark Lewisohn wrote, "They pulled into Hamburg at dusk on 17 August, the time when the <a href="/wiki/Red-light_district" title="Red-light district">red-light area</a> comes to life&#160;... flashing neon lights screamed out the various entertainment on offer, while scantily clad women sat unabashed in shop windows waiting for business opportunities."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Koschmider had converted a couple of strip clubs in the district into music venues, and he initially placed the Beatles at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_in_Hamburg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles in Hamburg (page does not exist)">Indra Club</a>. After closing the Indra due to noise complaints, he moved them to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kaiserkeller&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kaiserkeller (page does not exist)">Kaiserkeller</a> in October.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> When he learned they had been performing at the rival <a href="/w/index.php?title=Top_Ten_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Top Ten Club (page does not exist)">Top Ten Club</a> in breach of their contract, he gave the band one month's termination notice,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and reported the underage Harrison, who had obtained permission to stay in Hamburg by lying to the German authorities about his age.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The authorities arranged for Harrison's deportation in late November.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> One week later, Koschmider had McCartney and Best arrested for arson after they set fire to a tapestry on the wall in their room; the authorities deported them.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon returned to Liverpool in early December, while Sutcliffe remained in Hamburg through late February with his German fiancée <a href="/wiki/Astrid_Kirchherr" title="Astrid Kirchherr">Astrid Kirchherr</a>,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> who took the first semi-professional photos of the Beatles.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>During the next two years, the Beatles were resident for periods in Hamburg, where they used <a href="/wiki/Phenmetrazine" title="Phenmetrazine">Preludin</a> both recreationally and to maintain their energy through all-night performances.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1961, during their second Hamburg engagement, Kirchherr cut Sutcliffe's hair in the "exi" (existentialist) style, later adopted by the other Beatles.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> When Sutcliffe decided to leave the band early that year and resume his art studies in Germany, McCartney took up the bass.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Producer <a href="/wiki/Bert_Kaempfert" title="Bert Kaempfert">Bert Kaempfert</a> contracted what was now a four-piece group through June 1962, and he used them as <a href="/wiki/Tony_Sheridan" title="Tony Sheridan">Tony Sheridan</a>'s <a href="/w/index.php?title=Backup_band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Backup band (page does not exist)">backing band</a> on a series of recordings.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p><p>After completing their second Hamburg residency, the Beatles enjoyed increasing popularity in Liverpool with the growing <a href="/wiki/Beat_music" title="Beat music">Merseybeat</a> movement. However, they were also growing tired of the monotony of numerous appearances at the same clubs night after night.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In November, during one of the group's frequent appearances at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Cavern_Club&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Cavern Club (page does not exist)">Cavern Club</a>, they encountered Brian Epstein, a local record store owner and music columnist.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He later recalled, "I immediately liked what I heard. They were fresh, and they were honest, and they had what I thought was a sort of presence&#160;... [a] star quality."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Epstein courted the band over the next couple of months, and they appointed him manager in January 1962.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> After an early February audition, <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_Decca_audition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles' Decca audition (page does not exist)">Decca Records rejected the band</a> with the comment "Guitar groups are on the way out, Mr. Epstein."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> Tragedy greeted them upon their return to Germany in April, when a distraught Kirchherr met them at the airport with news of Sutcliffe's death the previous day from what would later be determined a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cerebral_hemorrhage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cerebral hemorrhage (page does not exist)">brain haemorrhage</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The following month, George Martin signed the Beatles to <a href="/wiki/EMI" title="EMI">EMI</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Parlophone" title="Parlophone">Parlophone</a> label.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Abbey_Rd_Studios.jpg" title="File:Abbey Rd Studios.jpg">File:Abbey Rd Studios.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Abbey Road Studios main entrance</div></div></div>
<p>Martin's first recording session with the Beatles took place at EMI's <a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road_Studios" title="Abbey Road Studios">Abbey Road Studios</a> in London on 6 June 1962.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin immediately complained to Epstein about Best's poor drumming and suggested they use a <a href="/wiki/Session_musician" title="Session musician">session drummer</a> in his stead.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Already contemplating Best's dismissal,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> the Beatles replaced him in mid-August with Ringo Starr, who left <a href="/wiki/Rory_Storm_and_the_Hurricanes" title="Rory Storm and the Hurricanes" class="mw-redirect">Rory Storm and the Hurricanes</a> to join them.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> A 4 September session at EMI yielded a recording of "<a href="/wiki/Love_Me_Do" title="Love Me Do">Love Me Do</a>" featuring Starr on drums, but a dissatisfied Martin hired drummer <a href="/wiki/Andy_White_(drummer)" title="Andy White (drummer)">Andy White</a> for the band's third session a week later, which produced recordings of "Love Me Do", "<a href="/wiki/Please_Please_Me_(song)" title="Please Please Me (song)">Please Please Me</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=P.S._I_Love_You_(The_Beatles_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="P.S. I Love You (The Beatles song) (page does not exist)">P.S. I Love You</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin initially selected the Starr version of "Love Me Do" for the band's first single, though subsequent re-pressings featured the White version, with Starr on tambourine.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Released in early October, "Love Me Do" peaked at number seventeen on the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Record_Retailer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Record Retailer (page does not exist)">Record Retailer</a></i> chart.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their television début came later that month with a live performance on the regional news programme <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Granada_Reports&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Granada Reports (page does not exist)">People and Places</a></i>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> A studio session in late November yielded another recording of "Please Please Me",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> of which Martin accurately predicted, "You've just made your first No.1."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In December 1962, the Beatles concluded their fifth and final Hamburg residency.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> By 1963, they had agreed that all four band members would contribute vocals to their albums—including Starr, despite his restricted vocal range, to validate his standing in the group.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon and McCartney had established a songwriting partnership, and as the band's success grew, their dominant collaboration limited Harrison's opportunities as a lead vocalist.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Epstein, in an effort to maximize the Beatles' commercial potential, encouraged them to adopt a professional approach to performing.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon recalled him saying, "Look, if you really want to get in these bigger places, you're going to have to change—stop eating on stage, stop swearing, stop smoking".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon said, "We used to dress how we liked, on and off stage. He'd tell us that jeans were not particularly smart and could we possibly manage to wear proper trousers, but he didn't want us suddenly looking square. He'd let us have our own sense of individuality".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1963.E2.80.9366:_Beatlemania_and_touring_years">1963–66: Beatlemania and touring years</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Please_Please_Me_and_With_the_Beatles"><i>Please Please Me</i> and <i>With the Beatles</i></span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Beatles_logo.svg" title="File:Beatles logo.svg">File:Beatles logo.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Their logo was based on an impromptu sketch by instrument retailer and designer Ivor Arbiter.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a></div></div></div>
<p>In February 1963, the Beatles recorded ten songs during a single marathon studio session for their debut LP, <i>Please Please Me</i>. The album was supplemented by the four tracks already released on their first two singles.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> After the moderate success of "Love Me Do", "Please Please Me" met with a more emphatic reception. Released in January 1963, two months ahead of the album of the same name, the song reached number one on every chart in London except <i>Record Retailer</i>, where it stalled at number two.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Recalling how the Beatles "rushed to deliver a debut album, bashing out <i>Please Please Me</i> in a day", <a href="/w/index.php?title=Allmusic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Allmusic (page does not exist)">Allmusic</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Thomas_Erlewine" title="Stephen Thomas Erlewine">Stephen Thomas Erlewine</a> comments, "Decades after its release, the album still sounds fresh, precisely because of its intense origins."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon said little thought went into composition at the time; he and McCartney were "just writing songs <i>à la</i> <a href="/wiki/The_Everly_Brothers" title="The Everly Brothers">Everly Brothers</a>, <i>à la</i> Buddy Holly, pop songs with no more thought of them than that—to create a sound. And the words were almost irrelevant."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Released in March 1963, the album initiated a run during which eleven of their twelve studio albums released in the United Kingdom through 1970 reached number one.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The band's third single, "<a href="/wiki/From_Me_to_You" title="From Me to You">From Me to You</a>", came out in April and was also a chart-topping hit, starting an almost unbroken string of seventeen British number one singles for the Beatles, including all but one of the eighteen they released over the next six years.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Released in August, the band's fourth single, "<a href="/wiki/She_Loves_You" title="She Loves You">She Loves You</a>", achieved the fastest sales of any record in the UK up to that time, selling three-quarters of a million copies in under four weeks.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It became their first single to sell a million copies, and remained the biggest-selling record in the UK until 1978, when "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Mull_of_Kintyre_(song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mull of Kintyre (song) (page does not exist)">Mull of Kintyre</a>", by McCartney's post-Beatles band <a href="/wiki/Wings_(band)" title="Wings (band)">Wings</a>, surpassed it in sales.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their commercial success brought increased media exposure, to which the Beatles responded with an irreverent and comical attitude that defied the expectations of pop musicians at the time, inspiring even more interest.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> As their popularity spread, a frenzied adulation of the group took hold. Greeted with riotous enthusiasm by screaming fans, the press dubbed the phenomenon "Beatlemania".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_and_Lill-Babs_1963.jpg" title="File:The Beatles and Lill-Babs 1963.jpg">File:The Beatles and Lill-Babs 1963.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">McCartney, Harrison, Swedish pop singer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lill-Babs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lill-Babs (page does not exist)">Lill-Babs</a> and Lennon on the set of the Swedish television show <i>Drop-In</i>, 30 October 1963<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a></div></div></div>
<p>In late October, the Beatles began a five-day tour of Sweden, their first time abroad since the final Hamburg engagement of December 1962.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Upon their return to the UK on 31 October, "several hundred screaming fans" greeted them in heavy rain at <a href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Airport" title="London Heathrow Airport">Heathrow Airport</a> wrote Lewisohn. Around fifty to a hundred journalists and photographers as well as representatives from the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Television" title="BBC Television">BBC</a> also joined the airport reception, the first of more than one hundred such events.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The next day, they began their fourth tour of Britain within nine months, this one scheduled for six weeks.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In mid-November, as Beatlemania intensified, police resorted to using high-pressure water hoses to control the crowd before a concert in Plymouth.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p><i>Please Please Me</i> maintained the top position on the <i>Record Retailer</i> chart for thirty weeks, only to be displaced by their follow-up, <i><a href="/wiki/With_the_Beatles" title="With the Beatles">With the Beatles</a></i>, which EMI delayed the release of until sales of <i>Please Please Me</i> had subsided.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> Recorded between July and October, <i>With the Beatles</i> made better use of studio production techniques than its predecessor.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It held the top spot for twenty-one weeks with a chart life of 40 weeks.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Erlewine described the LP as "a sequel of the highest order—one that betters the original".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> The album caught the attention of music critic <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Mann_(critic)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Mann (critic) (page does not exist)">William Mann</a> of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>, who suggested that Lennon and McCartney were "the outstanding English composers of 1963".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The newspaper published a series of articles in which Mann offered detailed analyses of the music, lending it respectability.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i>With the Beatles</i> became the second album in UK chart history to sell a million copies, a figure previously reached only by the 1958 <i><a href="/wiki/South_Pacific_(musical)" title="South Pacific (musical)">South Pacific</a></i> soundtrack.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In writing the sleeve notes for the album, the band's press officer, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tony_Barrow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tony Barrow (page does not exist)">Tony Barrow</a> used the superlative the "fabulous foursome", which the media widely adopted as the "Fab Four".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id=".22British_Invasion.22">"British Invasion"</span></h4>
<p>EMI's American subsidiary, <a href="/wiki/Capitol_Records" title="Capitol Records">Capitol Records</a>, hindered the Beatles' releases in the United States for more than a year by initially declining to issue their music, including their first three singles. Concurrent negotiations with the independent US labels <a href="/wiki/Vee-Jay" title="Vee-Jay" class="mw-redirect">Vee-Jay</a> and <a href="/wiki/Swan_Records" title="Swan Records">Swan</a> led to the release of the songs in 1963,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> but legal issues with royalties and publishing rights proved an obstacle to the successful marketing of the group in the US.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> American chart success began after Epstein arranged for a $40,000 US marketing campaign and secured the support of disk jockey Carrol James, who first played the band's records in mid-December 1963, initiating their music's spread across US radio. This caused an increase in demand, leading Capitol to rush-release "I Want to Hold Your Hand" later that month.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Released 26 December 1963, with the band's previously scheduled debut there just weeks away, "I Want to Hold Your Hand" sold a million copies, becoming a number one hit in the US by mid-January.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_in_America.JPG" title="File:The Beatles in America.JPG">File:The Beatles in America.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Beatles arrive at John F. Kennedy International Airport, 7 February 1964</div></div></div>
<p>On 7 February 1964, the Beatles left the United Kingdom with an estimated four thousand fans gathered at Heathrow, waving and screaming as the aircraft took off.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Upon landing at New York's <a href="/wiki/John_F._Kennedy_International_Airport" title="John F. Kennedy International Airport">John F. Kennedy Airport</a>, an uproarious crowd estimated at three thousand greeted them.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They gave their first live US television performance two days later on <i><a href="/wiki/The_Ed_Sullivan_Show" title="The Ed Sullivan Show">The Ed Sullivan Show</a></i>, watched by approximately 73 million viewers in over 23 million households,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> or 34 percent of the American population. According to the Nielsen rating service, it was "the largest audience that had ever been recorded for an American television <span lang="en-US">program</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>", wrote biographer Jonathan Gould.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The next morning, the Beatles awoke to a negative critical consensus in the US,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> but a day later their first US concert saw Beatlemania erupt at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Coliseum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Coliseum (page does not exist)">Washington Coliseum</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Back in New York the following day, the Beatles met with another strong reception during two shows at <a href="/wiki/Carnegie_Hall" title="Carnegie Hall">Carnegie Hall</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The band then flew to Florida and appeared on the weekly <i>Ed Sullivan Show</i> a second time, before another 70 million viewers, before returning to the UK on 22 February.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="A_Hard_Day.27s_Night"><i>A Hard Day's Night</i></span></h4>
<p>Capitol Records' lack of interest throughout 1963 had not gone unnoticed, and a competitor, <a href="/wiki/United_Artists_Records" title="United Artists Records">United Artists Records</a>, encouraged <a href="/wiki/United_Artists" title="United Artists">their film division</a> to offer the group a three-motion-picture deal, primarily for the commercial potential of the soundtracks.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Directed by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Lester" title="Richard Lester">Richard Lester</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(film)" title="A Hard Day's Night (film)">A Hard Day's Night</a></i> involved the band for six weeks in March–April 1964 as they played themselves in a <a href="/wiki/Mockumentary" title="Mockumentary">mock-documentary</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The film premiered in London and New York in July and August, respectively, and was an international success, with some critics drawing comparison with the Marx Brothers.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> According to Erlewine, the accompanying soundtrack album, <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(album)" title="A Hard Day's Night (album)">A Hard Day's Night</a></i>, saw them "truly coming into their own as a band. All of the disparate influences on their first two albums had coalesced into a bright, joyous, original sound, filled with ringing guitars and irresistible melodies."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> That "ringing guitar" sound was primarily the product of Harrison's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rickenbacker_360/12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rickenbacker 360/12 (page does not exist)">12-string electric Rickenbacker</a>, a prototype given him by the manufacturer, which made its debut on the record.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p><p>During the week of 4 April 1964, the Beatles held twelve positions on the <i>Billboard</i> Hot 100 singles chart, including the top five.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> Their popularity generated unprecedented interest in British music, and a number of other UK acts subsequently made their own American debuts, successfully touring over the next three years in what was termed the British Invasion.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their hairstyle, unusually long for the era and mocked by many adults, became an emblem of rebellion to the burgeoning youth culture.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Paul,_George_%26_John.png" title="File:Paul, George &amp; John.png">File:Paul, George &amp; John.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">McCartney, Harrison and Lennon perform on Dutch television in 1964</div></div></div>
<p>Touring internationally in June and July, the Beatles staged thirty-seven shows over twenty-seven days in Denmark, the Netherlands, Hong Kong, Australia and New Zealand.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a> In August they returned to the US, with a thirty-concert tour of twenty-three cities.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Generating intense interest once again, the month-long tour attracted between ten and twenty thousand fans to each thirty-minute performance in cities from San Francisco to New York.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In August, journalist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Al_Aronowitz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Al Aronowitz (page does not exist)">Al Aronowitz</a> arranged for the Beatles to meet <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bob_Dylan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bob Dylan (page does not exist)">Bob Dylan</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Visiting the band in their New York hotel suite, Dylan introduced them to <a href="/wiki/Cannabis_(drug)" title="Cannabis (drug)">cannabis</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Gould points out the musical and cultural significance of this meeting, before which the musicians' respective fanbases were "perceived as inhabiting two separate subcultural worlds": Dylan's audience of "college kids with artistic or intellectual leanings, a dawning political and social idealism, and a mildly bohemian style" contrasted with their fans, "veritable '<a href="/wiki/Teenybopper" title="Teenybopper">teenyboppers</a>'—kids in high school or grade school whose lives were totally wrapped up in the commercialized popular culture of television, radio, pop records, fan magazines, and teen fashion. They were seen as idolaters, not idealists."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Within six months of the meeting, "Lennon would be making records on which he openly imitated Dylan's nasal drone, brittle strum, and introspective vocal persona", wrote Gould.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Within a year, Dylan would "proceed, with the help of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Electric_Dylan_controversy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Electric Dylan controversy (page does not exist)">a five-piece group and a Fender Stratocaster electric guitar</a>, to shake the monkey of folk <a href="/wiki/Authenticity_(philosophy)" title="Authenticity (philosophy)">authenticity</a> permanently off his back&#160;... the distinctions between the folk and rock audiences would have nearly evaporated [and the group's] audience&#160;... [was] showing signs of growing up."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Beatles_for_Sale.2C_Help.21_and_Rubber_Soul"><i>Beatles for Sale</i>, <i>Help!</i> and <i>Rubber Soul</i></span></h4>
<p>According to Gould, <i><a href="/wiki/Beatles_for_Sale" title="Beatles for Sale">Beatles for Sale</a></i>, the Beatles' fourth studio LP, evidenced a growing conflict between the commercial pressures of their global success and their creative ambitions.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They had intended the album, recorded between August and October 1964,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> to continue the format established by <i>A Hard Day's Night</i> which, unlike the band's first two LPs, contained only original songs.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The band, however, had nearly exhausted their backlog of songs on the previous album, and given the challenges constant international touring posed to the band's songwriting efforts, Lennon admitted, "Material's becoming a hell of a problem".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> As a result, six covers from their extensive repertoire were chosen to complete the album. Released in early December, its eight original compositions stood out, demonstrating the growing maturity of the <a href="/wiki/Lennon%E2%80%93McCartney" title="Lennon–McCartney">Lennon–McCartney</a> songwriting partnership.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In early 1965, while they were his guests for dinner, Lennon and Harrison's dentist secretly added <a href="/wiki/Lysergic_acid_diethylamide" title="Lysergic acid diethylamide">LSD</a> to their coffee. Lennon described the experience: "It was just terrifying, but it was fantastic. I was pretty stunned for a month or two."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He and Harrison subsequently became regular users of the drug, joined by Starr on at least one occasion. McCartney was initially reluctant to try it, but eventually did so in late 1966.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He became the first Beatle to discuss LSD publicly, declaring in a magazine interview that "it opened my eyes" and "made me a better, more honest, more tolerant member of society."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Controversy erupted in June 1965 when Queen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Elizabeth II</a> appointed all four Beatles <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Order of the British Empire">Members of the Order of the British Empire (MBE)</a> after Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Harold_Wilson" title="Harold Wilson">Harold Wilson</a> nominated them for the award.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In protest—the honour was at that time primarily bestowed upon military veterans and civic leaders—some conservative MBE recipients returned their own insignia.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TrailerUSHelp.jpg" title="File:TrailerUSHelp.jpg">File:TrailerUSHelp.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The US trailer for <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Help!_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Help! (film) (page does not exist)">Help!</a></i> with (from the rear) Harrison, McCartney, Lennon and (largely obscured) Starr</div></div></div>
<p>Released in July, the Beatles' second film, <i>Help!</i>, was directed by Lester. Described as "mainly a relentless spoof of <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Bond_(film_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Bond (film series) (page does not exist)">Bond</a>",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> it inspired a mixed response among both reviewers and the band. McCartney said, "<i>Help!</i> was great but it wasn't our film—we were sort of guest stars. It was fun, but basically, as an idea for a film, it was a bit wrong."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The soundtrack was dominated by Lennon, who wrote and sang lead on most of its songs, including the two singles: "<a href="/wiki/Help!_(song)" title="Help! (song)">Help!</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Ticket_to_Ride" title="Ticket to Ride">Ticket to Ride</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The accompanying album, the group's fifth studio LP, contained all original material save for two covers, "<a href="/wiki/Act_Naturally" title="Act Naturally">Act Naturally</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Dizzy,_Miss_Lizzy" title="Dizzy, Miss Lizzy">Dizzy Miss Lizzy</a>"; they were the last covers the band would include on an album, with the exception of <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be" title="Let It Be">Let It Be</a>'s</i> brief rendition of the traditional Liverpool folk song "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Maggie_May_(traditional_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maggie May (traditional song) (page does not exist)">Maggie Mae</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The band expanded their use of vocal overdubs on <i><a href="/wiki/Help!_(album)" title="Help! (album)">Help!</a></i> and incorporated classical instruments into some arrangements, notably the string quartet on the pop ballad "<a href="/wiki/Yesterday" title="Yesterday">Yesterday</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Composed by McCartney, "Yesterday" would inspire the most recorded cover versions of any song ever written.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The group's third US tour opened with a performance before a world-record crowd of 55,600 at New York's <a href="/wiki/Shea_Stadium" title="Shea Stadium">Shea Stadium</a> on 15 August 1965—"perhaps the most famous of all Beatles' concerts", in Lewisohn's description.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> A further nine successful concerts followed in other American cities. At a show in Atlanta, the Beatles gave one of the first live performances ever to make use of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Foldback_(sound_engineering)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Foldback (sound engineering) (page does not exist)">foldback</a> system of on-stage monitor speakers.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Towards the end of the tour they were granted an audience with <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a>, a foundational musical influence on the band, who invited them to his home in <a href="/wiki/Beverly_Hills,_California" title="Beverly Hills, California">Beverly Hills</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Side_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Side box (page does not exist)">Template:Side box</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
</p><p>In mid-October 1965, the Beatles entered the recording studio; for the first time in making an album, they had an extended period without other major commitments.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Released in December, <i>Rubber Soul</i> has been hailed by critics as a major step forward in the maturity and complexity of the band's music.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their thematic reach was beginning to expand as they embraced deeper aspects of romance and philosophy.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Biographers Peter Brown and Steven Gaines attribute the new musical direction to "the Beatles' now habitual use of marijuana",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> an assertion confirmed by the band—Lennon referred to it as "the pot album",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and Starr said, "Grass was really influential in a lot of our changes, especially with the writers. And because they were writing different material, we were playing differently."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> After <i>Help!'s</i> foray into the world of classical music with flutes and strings, Harrison's introduction of a <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a> on "<a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Wood_(This_Bird_Has_Flown)" title="Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)">Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)</a>" marked a further progression outside the traditional boundaries of popular music. As their lyrics grew more artful, fans began to study them for deeper meaning. Of "Norwegian Wood" Lennon commented: "I was trying to be sophisticated in writing about an affair&#160;... but in such a smokescreen way that you couldn't tell."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>While many of <i>Rubber Soul</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> more notable songs were the product of Lennon and McCartney's collaborative songwriting,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> it also featured distinct compositions from each,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> though they continued to share official credit. The song "<a href="/wiki/In_My_Life" title="In My Life">In My Life</a>", of which each later claimed lead authorship, is considered a highlight of the entire Lennon–McCartney catalogue.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Harrison called <i>Rubber Soul</i> his "favorite album"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and Starr referred to it as "the departure record".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney said, "We'd had our cute period, and now it was time to expand."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> However, recording engineer <a href="/wiki/Norman_Smith_(record_producer)" title="Norman Smith (record producer)">Norman Smith</a> later stated that the studio sessions revealed signs of growing conflict within the group—"the clash between John and Paul was becoming obvious", he wrote, and "as far as Paul was concerned, George could do no right".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 2003, <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> ranked <i>Rubber Soul</i> fifth among "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_500_Greatest_Albums_of_All_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time (page does not exist)">The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time</a>",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and Allmusic's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richie_Unterberger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richie Unterberger (page does not exist)">Richie Unterberger</a> describes it as "one of the classic <a href="/wiki/Folk_rock" title="Folk rock">folk-rock</a> records."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1966.E2.80.9370:_controversy.2C_studio_years_and_break-up">1966–70: controversy, studio years and break-up</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Events_leading_up_to_final_tour">Events leading up to final tour</span></h4>
<p>In June 1966, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yesterday_and_Today&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yesterday and Today (page does not exist)">Yesterday and Today</a></i>—one of the compilation albums created by Capitol Records for the US market—caused an uproar with its cover, which portrayed the grinning Beatles dressed in butcher's overalls, accompanied by raw meat and mutilated plastic baby dolls. It has been suggested that this was meant as a satirical response to the way Capitol had "butchered" the US versions of their albums.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Thousands of copies of the album had a new cover pasted over the original; an unpeeled "first-state" copy fetched $10,500 at a December 2005 auction.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In England, meanwhile, Harrison met sitar maestro <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Shankar" title="Ravi Shankar">Ravi Shankar</a>, who agreed to train him on the instrument.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>During a tour of the Philippines the month after the <i>Yesterday and Today</i> furore, the Beatles unintentionally snubbed the nation's first lady, <a href="/wiki/Imelda_Marcos" title="Imelda Marcos">Imelda Marcos</a>, who had expected them to attend a breakfast reception at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malaca%C3%B1an_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malacañan Palace (page does not exist)">Presidential Palace</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> When presented with the invitation, Epstein politely declined on the band members' behalf, as it had never been his policy to accept such official invitations.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They soon found that the Marcos regime was unaccustomed to taking no for an answer. The resulting riots endangered the group and they escaped the country with difficulty.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Immediately afterward, the band members visited India for the first time.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Almost as soon as they returned home, they faced a fierce backlash from US religious and social conservatives (as well as the <a href="/wiki/Ku_Klux_Klan" title="Ku Klux Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a>) over a comment Lennon had made in a March interview with British reporter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maureen_Cleave&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maureen Cleave (page does not exist)">Maureen Cleave</a>:<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> "Christianity will go," Lennon said. "It will vanish and shrink. I needn't argue about that; I'm right and I will be proved right. We're <a href="/w/index.php?title=More_popular_than_Jesus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="More popular than Jesus (page does not exist)">more popular than Jesus</a> now; I don't know which will go first, rock 'n' roll or Christianity. Jesus was alright but his disciples were thick and ordinary. It's them twisting it that ruins it for me."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The comment went virtually unnoticed in England, but when US teenage fan magazine <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Datebook&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Datebook (page does not exist)">Datebook</a></i> printed it five months later—on the eve of the group's August US tour—it sparked a controversy with Christians in the American "<a href="/wiki/Bible_Belt" title="Bible Belt">Bible Belt</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The Vatican issued a protest, and bans on Beatles' records were imposed by Spanish and Dutch stations and South Africa's national broadcasting service.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Epstein accused <i>Datebook</i> of having taken Lennon's words out of context; at a press conference Lennon pointed out, "If I'd said television was more popular than Jesus, I might have got away with it."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon claimed he was referring to how other people viewed their success, but at the prompting of reporters, he concluded, "If you want me to apologize, if that will make you happy, then okay, I'm sorry."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>As preparations were made for the US tour, the Beatles knew that their music would hardly be heard. Having originally used <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vox_AC30&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vox AC30 (page does not exist)">Vox AC30</a> amplifiers, they later acquired more powerful 100-watt amplifiers, specially designed by <a href="/wiki/Vox_(musical_equipment)" title="Vox (musical equipment)">Vox</a> for them as they moved into larger venues in 1964, but these were still inadequate. Struggling to compete with the volume of sound generated by screaming fans, the band had grown increasingly bored with the routine of performing live.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Recognizing that their shows were no longer about the music, they decided to make the August tour their last.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Revolver_and_Sgt._Pepper.27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band"><i>Revolver</i> and <i>Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</i></span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Side_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Side box (page does not exist)">Template:Side box</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
</p><p><i>Rubber Soul</i> had marked a major step forward; <i>Revolver</i>, released in August 1966 a week before the Beatles' final tour, marked another.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <a href="/wiki/Pitchfork_Media" title="Pitchfork Media">Pitchfork</a>'s Scott Plagenhoef identifies it as "the sound of a band growing into supreme confidence" and "redefining what was expected from popular music."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i>Revolver</i> featured sophisticated songwriting, studio experimentation, and a greatly expanded repertoire of musical styles ranging from innovative classical string arrangements to psychedelic rock.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Abandoning the customary group photograph, its cover—designed by <a href="/wiki/Klaus_Voormann" title="Klaus Voormann">Klaus Voormann</a>, a friend of the band since their Hamburg days—"was a stark, arty, black-and-white collage that caricatured the Beatles in a pen-and-ink style beholden to <a href="/wiki/Aubrey_Beardsley" title="Aubrey Beardsley">Aubrey Beardsley</a>", in Gould's description.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The album was preceded by the single "<a href="/wiki/Paperback_Writer" title="Paperback Writer">Paperback Writer</a>", backed by "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rain_(The_Beatles_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rain (The Beatles song) (page does not exist)">Rain</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Short promotional films were made for both songs, described by cultural historian Saul Austerlitz as "among the first true music videos",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> they aired on <i>The Ed Sullivan Show</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Top_of_the_Pops" title="Top of the Pops">Top of the Pops</a></i> in June 1966.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Among <i>Revolver</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> experimental songs was "<a href="/wiki/Tomorrow_Never_Knows" title="Tomorrow Never Knows">Tomorrow Never Knows</a>", for whose lyrics Lennon drew from <a href="/wiki/Timothy_Leary" title="Timothy Leary">Timothy Leary</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Psychedelic_Experience:_A_Manual_Based_on_the_Tibetan_Book_of_the_Dead&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead (page does not exist)">The Psychedelic Experience: A Manual Based on the Tibetan Book of the Dead</a></i>. Its creation involved eight tape decks distributed about the EMI building, each manned by an engineer or band member, who randomly varied the movement of a tape loop while Martin created a composite recording by sampling the incoming data.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney's "Eleanor Rigby" made prominent use of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Octet_(music)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Octet (music) (page does not exist)">string octet</a>; Gould describes it as "a true hybrid, conforming to no recognizable style or genre of song."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Harrison was developing as a songwriter, and three of his compositions earned a place on the record.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 2003, <i>Rolling Stone</i> ranked <i>Revolver</i> as the third greatest album of all time.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> During the US tour that followed its release, however, the band performed none of its songs.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> As Chris Ingham explains, they were very much "studio creations&#160;... and there was no way a four-piece rock 'n' roll group could do them justice, particularly through the desensitising wall of the fans' screams. 'Live Beatles' and 'Studio Beatles' had become entirely different beasts."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their final concert at San Francisco's <a href="/wiki/Candlestick_Park" title="Candlestick Park">Candlestick Park</a> on 29 August was their last commercial concert.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It marked the end of a four-year period dominated by almost nonstop touring that included over 1,400 concert appearances internationally.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Freed from the burden of touring, the Beatles embraced an increasingly experimental approach as they recorded <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i>, beginning in late November 1966.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> According to engineer <a href="/wiki/Geoff_Emerick" title="Geoff Emerick">Geoff Emerick</a>, the album's recording took over seven hundred hours.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He recalled the band's insistence "that everything on <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> had to be different. We had microphones right down in the bells of brass instruments and headphones turned into microphones attached to violins. We used giant primitive oscillators to vary the speed of instruments and vocals and we had tapes chopped to pieces and stuck together upside down and the wrong way around."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Parts of "<a href="/wiki/A_Day_in_the_Life" title="A Day in the Life">A Day in the Life</a>" featured a forty-piece orchestra.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The sessions initially yielded the non-album <a href="/wiki/Double_A-side" title="Double A-side" class="mw-redirect">double A-side</a> single "<a href="/wiki/Strawberry_Fields_Forever" title="Strawberry Fields Forever">Strawberry Fields Forever</a>"/"<a href="/wiki/Penny_Lane" title="Penny Lane">Penny Lane</a>" in February 1967;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> the <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> LP followed in June.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
