</p><p>The musical complexity of the records, created using relatively primitive <a href="/wiki/Multitrack_recording" title="Multitrack recording">four-track</a> recording technology, astounded contemporary artists.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> For <a href="/wiki/The_Beach_Boys" title="The Beach Boys">Beach Boys</a> leader <a href="/wiki/Brian_Wilson" title="Brian Wilson">Brian Wilson</a>, in the midst of a personal crisis and struggling to complete the ambitious <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Smile_(The_Beach_Boys_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Smile (The Beach Boys album) (page does not exist)">Smile</a></i>, hearing "Strawberry Fields" was a crushing blow and he soon abandoned all attempts to compete with his friendly rivals.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Among music critics, acclaim for the album was virtually universal.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Gould:
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Blockquote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Blockquote (page does not exist)">Template:Blockquote</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band.jpg" title="File:Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.jpg">File:Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Front cover of <i>Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</i>, "the most famous cover of any music album, and one of the most imitated images in the world."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a></div></div></div>
<p><i>Sgt. Pepper</i> was the first major pop/rock LP to include its complete lyrics, which appeared on the back cover.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Those lyrics were the subject of critical analysis; for instance, in late 1967 the album was the subject of a scholarly inquiry by American literary critic and professor of English <a href="/w/index.php?title=Richard_Poirier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Richard Poirier (page does not exist)">Richard Poirier</a>, who observed that his students were "listening to the group's music with a degree of engagement that he, as a teacher of literature, could only envy."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Poirier identified what he termed its "mixed allusiveness": "It's unwise ever to assume that they're doing only one thing or expressing themselves in only one style&#160;... one kind of feeling about a subject isn't enough&#160;... any single induced feeling must often exist within the context of seemingly contradictory alternatives."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney said at the time, "We write songs. We know what we mean by them. But in a week someone else says something about it, and you can't deny it.&#160;... You put your own meaning at your own level to our songs".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 2003, <i>Rolling Stone</i> ranked it number one on its list of the "500 Greatest Albums of All Time".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p><i>Sgt. Pepper</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> elaborate cover also attracted great interest and study:<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> a collage designed by <a href="/wiki/Pop_art" title="Pop art">pop artists</a> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Blake_(artist)" title="Peter Blake (artist)">Peter Blake</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jann_Haworth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jann Haworth (page does not exist)">Jann Haworth</a>, it depicted the group as the fictional band referred to in the album's <a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_(song)" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (song)">title track</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> standing in front of <a href="/wiki/List_of_images_on_the_cover_of_Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="List of images on the cover of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">a crowd of famous people</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The heavy moustaches worn by the group reflected the growing influence of <a href="/wiki/Hippie" title="Hippie">hippie</a> style,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> while cultural historian Jonathan Harris describes their "brightly coloured parodies of military uniforms" as a knowingly "anti-authoritarian and anti-establishment" display.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>On 25 June, the Beatles performed their forthcoming single, "<a href="/wiki/All_You_Need_Is_Love" title="All You Need Is Love">All You Need Is Love</a>", to an estimated 350 million viewers on <i><a href="/wiki/Our_World_(TV_special)" title="Our World (TV special)">Our World</a></i>, the first live global television link.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Released a week later during the <a href="/wiki/Summer_of_Love" title="Summer of Love">Summer of Love</a>, the song was adopted as a <a href="/wiki/Flower_power" title="Flower power">flower power</a> anthem.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Two months later the group suffered a loss that threw their career into turmoil. Having been introduced to <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a> only the previous night in London, on 25 August they travelled to <a href="/wiki/Bangor,_Gwynedd" title="Bangor, Gwynedd">Bangor</a> for his <a href="/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation" title="Transcendental Meditation">Transcendental Meditation</a> retreat. Two days later, their manager's assistant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Brown_(music_industry)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Brown (music industry) (page does not exist)">Peter Brown</a> phoned to inform them that Epstein had died.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The coroner ruled the death an accidental <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bromoureide&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bromoureide (page does not exist)">carbitol</a> overdose, though it was widely rumoured a suicide.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Epstein had been in a fragile emotional state, stressed by personal issues and concern that the band might not renew his management contract, due to expire in October, over discontent with his supervision of business matters, particularly regarding <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seltaeb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seltaeb (page does not exist)">Seltaeb</a>, the company that handled their US merchandising rights.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> His death left the group disorientated and fearful about the future. Lennon recalled, "We collapsed. I knew that we were in trouble then. I didn't really have any misconceptions about our ability to do anything other than play music, and I was scared. I thought, We've had it now."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Magical_Mystery_Tour.2C_White_Album_and_Yellow_Submarine"><i>Magical Mystery Tour</i>, <i>White Album</i> and <i>Yellow Submarine</i></span></h4>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/Magical_Mystery_Tour" title="Magical Mystery Tour">Magical Mystery Tour</a></i>; the soundtrack to a forthcoming Beatles television film, was released in the UK as a six-track double <a href="/wiki/Extended_play" title="Extended play">extended play disc (EP)</a> in early December 1967.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In the United States, the six songs were issued on an identically titled LP that also included five tracks from the band's recent singles.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Unterberger says of the US <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i>, "the psychedelic sound is very much in the vein of <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>, and even spacier in parts (especially the sound collages of '<a href="/wiki/I_Am_the_Walrus" title="I Am the Walrus">I Am the Walrus</a>')", and calls its five songs culled from the band's 1967 singles "huge, glorious, and innovative".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In its first three weeks, it set a record for the highest initial sales of any Capitol LP, and it is the only Capitol compilation later to be adopted in the band's official canon of studio albums.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> First aired on <a href="/wiki/Boxing_Day" title="Boxing Day">Boxing Day</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Magical_Mystery_Tour_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Magical Mystery Tour (film) (page does not exist)"><i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> film</a>, largely directed by McCartney, brought the group their first major negative UK press. It was dismissed as "blatant rubbish" by the <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Express" title="Daily Express">Daily Express</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mail" title="Daily Mail">Daily Mail</a></i> called it "a colossal conceit" and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Guardian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Guardian (page does not exist)">The Guardian</a></i> labelled it "a kind of fantasy morality play about the grossness and warmth and stupidity of the audience".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Gould describes it as "a great deal of raw footage showing a group of people getting on, getting off, and riding on a bus".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Although the viewership figures were respectable, its slating in the press led US television networks to lose interest in broadcasting it.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In January, the Beatles filmed a cameo for the animated movie <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow_Submarine_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow Submarine (film) (page does not exist)">Yellow Submarine</a></i>, which featured cartoon versions of the band members and a soundtrack with eleven of their songs, including four unreleased studio recordings which made their debut in the film.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Released in June 1968, it was praised by critics for its music, humour, and innovative visual style.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It would be seven months, however, before the film's soundtrack album appeared.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:TheBeatles68LP.jpg" title="File:TheBeatles68LP.jpg">File:TheBeatles68LP.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>The Beatles</i>, known as the <i>White Album</i> for its minimalist cover, conceived by pop artist <a href="/wiki/Richard_Hamilton_(artist)" title="Richard Hamilton (artist)">Richard Hamilton</a> "in direct contrast to <i>Sgt. Pepper</i>, while also suggesting a "clean slate."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a></div></div></div>
<p>In the interim came <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)">The Beatles</a></i>, a double LP commonly known as the <i>White Album</i> for its virtually featureless cover.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Creative inspiration for the album came from a new direction: without Epstein's guiding presence, the group had briefly turned to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi as their <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">guru</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> At his <a href="/wiki/Ashram" title="Ashram">ashram</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rishikesh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rishikesh (page does not exist)">Rishikesh</a>, India, a "Guide Course" scheduled for three months marked <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_in_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles in India (page does not exist)">one of their most prolific periods</a>, yielding numerous songs including a majority of the thirty included on the album.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> However, Starr left after only ten days, likening it to <a href="/wiki/Butlins" title="Butlins">Butlins</a>, and McCartney eventually grew bored and departed a month later.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> For Lennon and Harrison, creativity turned to questioning when an electronics technician known as <a href="/wiki/Magic_Alex" title="Magic Alex">Magic Alex</a> suggested that the Maharishi was attempting to manipulate them.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> When he alleged that the Maharishi had made sexual advances to women attendees, a persuaded Lennon left abruptly just two months into the course, bringing an unconvinced Harrison and the remainder of the group's entourage with him.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In anger Lennon wrote a scathing song titled "Maharishi", renamed "<a href="/wiki/Sexy_Sadie" title="Sexy Sadie">Sexy Sadie</a>" to avoid potential legal issues. McCartney said, "We made a mistake. We thought there was more to him than there was."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>During recording sessions for the album, which stretched from late May to mid-October 1968, relations between the Beatles grew openly divisive.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Starr quit for two weeks, and McCartney took over the drum kit for "<a href="/wiki/Back_in_the_U.S.S.R." title="Back in the U.S.S.R.">Back in the U.S.S.R.</a>" (on which Harrison and Lennon drummed as well) and "<a href="/wiki/Dear_Prudence" title="Dear Prudence">Dear Prudence</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon had lost interest in collaborating with McCartney,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> whose contribution "<a href="/wiki/Ob-La-Di,_Ob-La-Da" title="Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da">Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da</a>" he scorned as "granny music shit."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Tensions were further aggravated by Lennon's romantic preoccupation with avant-garde artist <a href="/wiki/Yoko_Ono" title="Yoko Ono">Yoko Ono</a>, whom he insisted on bringing to the sessions despite the group's well-established understanding that girlfriends were not allowed in the studio.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Describing the <i>White Album</i>, Lennon said, "Every track is an individual track; there isn't any Beatle music on it. [It's] John and the band, Paul and the band, George and the band."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney recalled that the album "wasn't a pleasant one to make."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Both he and Lennon identified the sessions as the start of the band's break-up.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Issued in November, the <i>White Album</i> was the band's first <a href="/wiki/Apple_Records" title="Apple Records">Apple Records</a> album release, though EMI continued to own their recordings.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The new label was a subsidiary of <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps</a>, formed as part of Epstein's plan to create a tax-effective business structure.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The record attracted more than two million advance orders, selling nearly four million copies in the US in little over a month, and its tracks dominated the playlists of American radio stations.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Despite its popularity, it did not receive flattering reviews at the time. According to Gould,
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Blockquote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Blockquote (page does not exist)">Template:Blockquote</a>
</p><p>General critical opinion eventually turned in favour of the <i>White Album</i>, and in 2003 <i>Rolling Stone</i> ranked it as the tenth greatest album of all time.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Pitchfork's Mark Richardson describes it as "large and sprawling, overflowing with ideas but also with indulgences, and filled with a hugely variable array of material&#160;... its failings are as essential to its character as its triumphs."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Erlewine comments, "The [band's] two main songwriting forces were no longer on the same page, but neither were George and Ringo", yet "Lennon turns in two of his best ballads", McCartney's songs are "stunning", Harrison had become "a songwriter who deserved wider exposure" and Starr's composition was "a delight".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow_Submarine_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow Submarine (album) (page does not exist)"><i>Yellow Submarine</i> LP</a>, issued in January 1969, contained only the four previously unreleased songs that had debuted in the film, along with the title track (already issued on <i>Revolver</i>), "All You Need Is Love" (already issued as a single and on the US <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> LP) and seven instrumental pieces composed by Martin.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Because of the paucity of new Beatles music, Allmusic's Unterberger and Bruce Eder suggest the album might be "inessential" but for Harrison's "<a href="/wiki/It%27s_All_Too_Much" title="It's All Too Much">It's All Too Much</a>": "the jewel of the new songs&#160;... resplendent in swirling <a href="/wiki/Mellotron" title="Mellotron">Mellotron</a>, larger-than-life percussion, and tidal waves of feedback guitar&#160;... a virtuoso excursion into otherwise hazy psychedelia".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div style="clear:right;"></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Abbey_Road.2C_Let_It_Be.2C_and_break-up"><i>Abbey Road</i>, <i>Let It Be</i>, and break-up</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:3_Savile_Row.jpg" title="File:3 Savile Row.jpg">File:3 Savile Row.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Apple Corps building at 3 Savile Row, site of the <i>Let It Be</i> <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles' rooftop concert (page does not exist)">rooftop concert</a></div></div></div>
<p>Although <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be" title="Let It Be">Let It Be</a></i> was the Beatles' final album release, it was largely recorded before <i>Abbey Road</i>. The project's impetus came from an idea Martin attributes to McCartney, who suggested they "record an album of new material and rehearse it, then perform it before a live audience for the very first time—on record and on film."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Originally intended for a one-hour television programme to be called "Beatles at Work", much of the album's content came from extensive rehearsals filmed by director <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Lindsay-Hogg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Lindsay-Hogg (page does not exist)">Michael Lindsay-Hogg</a> at <a href="/wiki/Twickenham_Film_Studios" title="Twickenham Film Studios">Twickenham Film Studios</a> beginning in January 1969.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin said the project was "not at all a happy recording experience. It was a time when relations between The Beatles were at their lowest".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon described the largely impromptu sessions as "hell&#160;... the most miserable&#160;... on Earth", and Harrison, "the low of all-time".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Irritated by both McCartney and Lennon, Harrison walked out for five days. Upon returning, he threatened to leave the band unless they "abandon[ed] all talk of live performance" and instead focus on finishing a new album, initially titled <i>Get Back</i>, using songs recorded for the TV special.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He also demanded they cease work at Twickenham and relocate to the newly finished Apple Studios. The other band members agreed, and the idea came about to salvage the footage shot for the TV production for use in a feature film.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In an effort to alleviate tensions within the band and improve the quality of their live sound, Harrison invited keyboardist <a href="/wiki/Billy_Preston" title="Billy Preston">Billy Preston</a> to participate in the last nine days of sessions.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Preston received label billing on the "<a href="/wiki/Get_Back" title="Get Back">Get Back</a>" single—the only musician ever to receive that acknowledgment on an official Beatles release.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> At the conclusion of the rehearsals, the band could not agree on a location to film a concert, rejecting several ideas, including a boat at sea, a lunatic asylum, the Tunisian desert, and the <a href="/wiki/Colosseum" title="Colosseum">Colosseum</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Ultimately, what would be their <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_rooftop_concert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles' rooftop concert (page does not exist)">final live performance</a> was filmed on the rooftop of the Apple Corps building at 3 <a href="/wiki/Savile_Row" title="Savile Row">Savile Row</a>, London, on 30 January 1969.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Five weeks later, engineer <a href="/wiki/Glyn_Johns" title="Glyn Johns">Glyn Johns</a>, whom Lewisohn describes as <i>Get Back'</i>s "uncredited producer", began work assembling an album, given "free rein" as the band "all but washed their hands of the entire project."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>New strains developed between the band members regarding the appointment of a financial adviser, the need for which had become evident without Epstein to manage business affairs. Lennon, Harrison and Starr favoured <a href="/wiki/Allen_Klein" title="Allen Klein">Allen Klein</a>, who had managed <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">the Rolling Stones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sam_Cooke" title="Sam Cooke">Sam Cooke</a>; McCartney wanted John Eastman, brother of <a href="/wiki/Linda_McCartney" title="Linda McCartney">Linda Eastman</a>, whom McCartney married on 12 March. Agreement could not be reached, so both were temporarily appointed, but further conflict ensued and financial opportunities were lost.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> On 8 May, Klein was named sole manager of the band.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Martin stated that he was surprised when McCartney asked him to produce another album, as the <i>Get Back</i> sessions had been "a miserable experience" and he had "thought it was the end of the road for all of us".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The primary recording sessions for <i>Abbey Road</i> began on 2 July.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon, who rejected Martin's proposed format of a "continuously moving piece of music", wanted his and McCartney's songs to occupy separate sides of the album.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The eventual format, with individually composed songs on the first side and the second consisting largely of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_musical_medleys&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of musical medleys (page does not exist)">medley</a>, was McCartney's suggested compromise.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> On 4 July, the first solo single by a Beatle was released: Lennon's "<a href="/wiki/Give_Peace_a_Chance" title="Give Peace a Chance">Give Peace a Chance</a>", credited to the <a href="/wiki/Plastic_Ono_Band" title="Plastic Ono Band">Plastic Ono Band</a>. The completion and mixing of "<a href="/wiki/I_Want_You_(She%27s_So_Heavy)" title="I Want You (She's So Heavy)">I Want You (She's So Heavy)</a>" on 20 August 1969 was the last occasion on which all four Beatles were together in the same studio.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Lennon announced his departure to the rest of the group on 20 September, but agreed to withhold a public announcement to avoid undermining sales of the forthcoming album.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Released six days after Lennon's declaration, <i>Abbey Road</i> sold four million copies within three months and topped the UK charts for a total of seventeen weeks.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Its second track, the ballad "<a href="/wiki/Something" title="Something">Something</a>", was issued as a single—the only Harrison composition ever to appear as a Beatles A-side.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i>Abbey Road</i> received mixed reviews, although the medley met with general acclaim.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Unterberger considers it "a fitting swan song for the group", containing "some of the greatest harmonies to be heard on any rock record".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> MacDonald calls it "erratic and often hollow", despite the "semblance of unity and coherence" offered by the medley.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin singled it out as his personal favourite of all the band's albums; Lennon said it was "competent" but had "no life in it". Recording engineer Emerick noted that the replacement of the studio's <a href="/wiki/Vacuum_tube" title="Vacuum tube">valve</a> mixing console with a transistorized one yielded a less punchy sound, leaving the group frustrated at the thinner tone and lack of impact and contributing to its "kinder, gentler" feel relative to their previous albums.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>For the still unfinished <i>Get Back</i> album, one last song, Harrison's "<a href="/wiki/I_Me_Mine" title="I Me Mine">I Me Mine</a>", was recorded on 3 January 1970. Lennon, in Denmark at the time, did not participate.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In March, rejecting the work Johns had done on the project, now retitled <i>Let It Be</i>, Klein gave the session tapes to American producer <a href="/w/index.php?title=Phil_Spector&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Phil Spector (page does not exist)">Phil Spector</a>, who had recently produced Lennon's solo single "<a href="/wiki/Instant_Karma!" title="Instant Karma!">Instant Karma!</a>"<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In addition to remixing the material, Spector edited, spliced and overdubbed several of the recordings that had been intended as "live". McCartney was unhappy with the producer's approach and particularly dissatisfied with the lavish orchestration on "<a href="/wiki/The_Long_and_Winding_Road" title="The Long and Winding Road">The Long and Winding Road</a>", which involved a fourteen-voice choir and thirty-six-piece instrumental ensemble.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney's demands that the alterations to the song be reverted were ignored,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and he publicly announced his departure from the band on 10 April 1970, a week before the release of his first, <a href="/wiki/McCartney_(album)" title="McCartney (album)">self-titled solo album</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>On 8 May, the Spector-produced <i>Let It Be</i> was released. Its accompanying single, "The Long and Winding Road", was the Beatles' last; it was released in the United States, but not Britain.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Let_It_Be_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Let It Be (film) (page does not exist)"><i>Let It Be</i> documentary film</a> followed later that month, and would win the 1970 Academy Award for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Music_(Scoring)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Music (Scoring) (page does not exist)">Best Original Song Score</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Sunday_Telegraph&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sunday Telegraph (page does not exist)">Sunday Telegraph</a></i> critic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Penelope_Gilliatt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Penelope Gilliatt (page does not exist)">Penelope Gilliatt</a> called it "a very bad film and a touching one&#160;... about the breaking apart of this reassuring, geometrically perfect, once apparently ageless family of siblings."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Several reviewers stated that some of the performances in the film sounded better than their analogous album tracks.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Describing <i>Let It Be</i> as the "only Beatles album to occasion negative, even hostile reviews", Unterberger calls it "on the whole underrated"; he singles out "some good moments of straight hard rock in '<a href="/wiki/I%27ve_Got_a_Feeling" title="I've Got a Feeling">I've Got a Feeling</a>' and '<a href="/wiki/Dig_a_Pony" title="Dig a Pony">Dig a Pony</a>'", and praises "<a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be_(song)" title="Let It Be (song)">Let It Be</a>", "Get Back", and "the folky '<a href="/wiki/Two_of_Us_(song)" title="Two of Us (song)">Two of Us</a>', with John and Paul harmonizing together".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney filed suit for the dissolution of the Beatles' contractual partnership on 31 December 1970.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Legal disputes continued long after their break-up, and the dissolution was not formalized until 29 December 1974.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1970.E2.80.93present:_after_the_break-up">1970–present: after the break-up</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1970s">1970s</span></h4>
<p>Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr all released solo albums in 1970. Their solo records sometimes involved one or more of the others;<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Starr's <i><a href="/wiki/Ringo_(album)" title="Ringo (album)">Ringo</a></i> (1973) was the only album to include compositions and performances by all four ex-Beatles, albeit on separate songs. With Starr's collaboration, Harrison staged <a href="/wiki/The_Concert_for_Bangladesh" title="The Concert for Bangladesh">The Concert for Bangladesh</a> in New York City in August 1971.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Other than an unreleased jam session in 1974, later <a href="/wiki/Bootleg_recording" title="Bootleg recording">bootlegged</a> as <i><a href="/wiki/A_Toot_and_a_Snore_in_%2774" title="A Toot and a Snore in '74">A Toot and a Snore in '74</a></i>, Lennon and McCartney never recorded together again.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Two double-LP sets of the Beatles' greatest hits, compiled by Klein, <i><a href="/wiki/1962%E2%80%931966" title="1962–1966">1962–1966</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/1967%E2%80%931970" title="1967–1970">1967–1970</a></i>, were released in 1973, at first under the Apple Records imprint.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Commonly known as the <i>Red Album</i> and <i>Blue Album</i> respectively, each earned a <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Multi-Platinum certification</a> in the United States and a Platinum certification in the United Kingdom.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Between 1976 and 1982, EMI/Capitol released a wave of compilation albums without input from the ex-Beatles, starting with the double-disc compilation <i><a href="/wiki/Rock_%27n%27_Roll_Music_(album)" title="Rock 'n' Roll Music (album)">Rock 'n' Roll Music</a></i>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The only one to feature previously unreleased material was <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_at_the_Hollywood_Bowl" title="The Beatles at the Hollywood Bowl">The Beatles at the Hollywood Bowl</a></i> (1977); the first officially issued concert recordings by the group, it contained selections from two shows they played during their 1964 and 1965 US tours.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p><p>The music and enduring fame of the Beatles has been commercially exploited in various other ways, again often outside their creative control. In April 1974, the musical <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=John,_Paul,_George,_Ringo_%E2%80%A6_and_Bert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John, Paul, George, Ringo … and Bert (page does not exist)">John, Paul, George, Ringo…&amp; Bert</a></i>, written by <a href="/wiki/Willy_Russell" title="Willy Russell">Willy Russell</a> and featuring singer <a href="/wiki/Barbara_Dickson" title="Barbara Dickson">Barbara Dickson</a> opened in London. It included, with permission from Northern Songs, eleven Lennon-McCartney compositions and one by Harrison, "<a href="/wiki/Here_Comes_the_Sun" title="Here Comes the Sun">Here Comes the Sun</a>". Displeased with the production's use of his song, Harrison withdrew his permission to use it.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=All_This_and_World_War_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="All This and World War II (page does not exist)">All This and World War II</a></i> (1976) was an unorthodox nonfiction film that combined newsreel footage with covers of Beatles songs by performers ranging from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elton_John&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elton John (page does not exist)">Elton John</a> and <a href="/wiki/Keith_Moon" title="Keith Moon">Keith Moon</a> to the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Orchestra" title="London Symphony Orchestra">London Symphony Orchestra</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The Broadway musical <i><a href="/wiki/Beatlemania_(musical)" title="Beatlemania (musical)">Beatlemania</a></i>, an unauthorized nostalgia revue, opened in early 1977 and proved popular, spinning off five separate touring productions.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>  In 1979, the band sued the producers, settling for several million dollars in damages.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band_(film)" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (film)">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i> (1978), a musical film starring the <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peter_Frampton" title="Peter Frampton">Peter Frampton</a>, was a commercial failure and an "artistic fiasco".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1980s">1980s</span></h4>
<p>After the December 1980 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Death_of_John_Lennon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Death of John Lennon (page does not exist)">murder</a> of Lennon, Harrison rewrote the lyrics to his song "<a href="/wiki/All_Those_Years_Ago" title="All Those Years Ago">All Those Years Ago</a>" in Lennon's honour. With McCartney and his wife, <a href="/wiki/Linda_McCartney" title="Linda McCartney">Linda</a>, contributing backing vocals and Starr on drums, the song was released as a single in May 1981.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney's own tribute, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Here_Today_(Paul_McCartney_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Here Today (Paul McCartney song) (page does not exist)">Here Today</a>", appeared on his <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tug_of_War_(Paul_McCartney_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tug of War (Paul McCartney album) (page does not exist)">Tug of War</a></i> album in April 1982.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1987 Harrison's <i><a href="/wiki/Cloud_Nine_(George_Harrison_album)" title="Cloud Nine (George Harrison album)">Cloud Nine</a></i> album included "<a href="/w/index.php?title=When_We_Was_Fab&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="When We Was Fab (page does not exist)">When We Was Fab</a>", a song about the Beatlemania era.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>When the Beatles' studio albums were released on CD by EMI and Apple Corps in 1987, their catalogue was standardized throughout the world, establishing a canon of the twelve original studio LPs as issued in the United Kingdom plus the US LP version of <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> (1967), which had been released as a shorter double EP in the UK.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> All of the remaining material from the singles and EPs which had not appeared on the original studio albums was gathered on the two-volume compilation <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Past_Masters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Past Masters (page does not exist)">Past Masters</a></i> (1988). Except for the <i>Red</i> and <i>Blue</i> albums, EMI deleted all its other Beatles compilations—including the <i>Hollywood Bowl</i> record—from its catalogue.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 1988, the Beatles were inducted into the <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a>, their first year of eligibility. Harrison and Starr attended the ceremony with Lennon's widow, Yoko Ono, and his two sons, <a href="/wiki/Julian_Lennon" title="Julian Lennon">Julian</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sean_Lennon" title="Sean Lennon">Sean</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney declined to attend, citing unresolved "business differences" that would make him "feel like a complete hypocrite waving and smiling with them at a fake reunion."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The following year, EMI/Capitol settled a decade-long lawsuit filed by the band over royalties, clearing the way to commercially package previously unreleased material.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="1990s">1990s</span></h4>
<p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Live_at_the_BBC_(The_Beatles_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Live at the BBC (The Beatles album) (page does not exist)">Live at the BBC</a></i>, the first official release of unissued Beatles performances in 17 years, appeared in 1994.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> That same year McCartney, Harrison and Starr collaborated on the <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_Anthology" title="The Beatles Anthology">Anthology</a></i> project. <i>Anthology</i> was the culmination of work begun in 1970, when <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Corps</a> director <a href="/wiki/Neil_Aspinall" title="Neil Aspinall">Neil Aspinall</a>, their former road manager and personal assistant, had started to gather material for a documentary with the working title <i>The Long and Winding Road</i>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Documenting their history in the band's own words, the <i>Anthology</i> project included the release of several unissued Beatles recordings. McCartney, Harrison and Starr also added new instrumental and vocal parts to two songs recorded as demos by Lennon in the late 1970s and early 1980s.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>During 1995 and 1996, the project yielded a television mini-series, an eight-volume video set and three two-CD box sets featuring artwork by Klaus Voormann. The two songs based on Lennon demos, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_as_a_Bird&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free as a Bird (page does not exist)">Free as a Bird</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Real_Love_(John_Lennon_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Real Love (John Lennon song) (page does not exist)">Real Love</a>", were released as new Beatles singles. The releases were commercially successful and the television series was viewed by an estimated 400 million people.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1999, to coincide with the re-release of the 1968 film <i>Yellow Submarine</i>, a new soundtrack compilation CD, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow_Submarine_Songtrack&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow Submarine Songtrack (page does not exist)">Yellow Submarine Songtrack</a></i>, was issued.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2000s">2000s</span></h4>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/1_(The_Beatles_album)" title="1 (The Beatles album)">1</a></i>, a compilation album of every British and American number one Beatles hit, was released on 13 November 2000. It became the fastest-selling album of all time with 3.6 million sold in its first week<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and 13 million within a month.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It was a number one hit in at least 28 countries, including the UK and US.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> As of April 2009 it had sold 31 million copies globally,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and was the best selling album of the decade in the United States.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Harrison died from <a href="/wiki/Metastasis" title="Metastasis">metastatic</a> lung cancer in November 2001.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> McCartney and Starr were among the musicians who performed at the <a href="/wiki/Concert_for_George" title="Concert for George">Concert for George</a>, organized by <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a> and Harrison's widow, <a href="/wiki/Olivia_Harrison" title="Olivia Harrison">Olivia</a>. The tribute event took place at the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> on the first anniversary of Harrison's death. In addition to songs he composed for the group and his own solo career, the concert included a celebration of <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Indian classical music</a>, which had significantly influenced Harrison.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 2003, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Let_It_Be..._Naked&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Let It Be... Naked (page does not exist)">Let It Be... Naked</a></i>, a reconceived version of the <i>Let It Be</i> album, with McCartney supervising production, was released. One of the main differences with the Spector-produced version was the omission of the original string arrangements.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> It was a top ten hit in both the UK and the US. The US album configurations from 1964–65 were released as box sets in 2004 and 2006—<i><a href="/wiki/The_Capitol_Albums,_Volume_1" title="The Capitol Albums, Volume 1">The Capitol Albums, Volume 1</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Capitol_Albums,_Volume_2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Capitol Albums, Volume 2 (page does not exist)">Volume 2</a></i> included both stereo and mono versions based on the mixes that were prepared for vinyl at the time of the music's original American release.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>As a soundtrack for <a href="/wiki/Cirque_du_Soleil" title="Cirque du Soleil">Cirque du Soleil</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip" title="Las Vegas Strip">Las Vegas</a> Beatles' stage revue <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_(Cirque_du_Soleil)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love (Cirque du Soleil) (page does not exist)">Love</a></i>, George Martin and his son <a href="/w/index.php?title=Giles_Martin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Giles Martin (page does not exist)">Giles</a> remixed and <a href="/wiki/Mashup_(music)" title="Mashup (music)">blended</a> 130 of the band's recordings to create what Martin called "a way of re-living the whole Beatles musical lifespan in a very condensed period".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The show premiered in June 2006, and the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Love_(The_Beatles_album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Love (The Beatles album) (page does not exist)">Love</a></i> album was released that November when McCartney discussed his hope that "<a href="/wiki/Carnival_of_Light" title="Carnival of Light">Carnival of Light</a>", a 14-minute experimental recording made at Abbey Road Studios in 1967, would receive an official release.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> A rare live performance involving two ex-Beatles took place in April 2009 at a benefit concert organized by McCartney at New York's <a href="/wiki/Radio_City_Music_Hall" title="Radio City Music Hall">Radio City Music Hall</a>, where he was joined by Starr for three songs.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ringo_Starr_e_Paul_Mcartney_-_E3_2009.jpg" title="File:Ringo Starr e Paul Mcartney - E3 2009.jpg">File:Ringo Starr e Paul Mcartney - E3 2009.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Starr and McCartney introduced the video game <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles:_Rock_Band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles: Rock Band (page does not exist)">The Beatles: Rock Band</a></i> at the 2009 <a href="/wiki/Electronic_Entertainment_Expo" title="Electronic Entertainment Expo">E3</a> convention</div></div></div>
<p>On 9 September 2009, the Beatles' entire back catalogue was reissued following an extensive digital remastering process that lasted four years.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Stereo editions of all twelve original UK studio albums, along with <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> and the <i>Past Masters</i> compilation, were released on compact disc both individually and <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_Stereo_Box_Set&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles Stereo Box Set (page does not exist)">as a box set</a>. Comparing the new releases with the 1987 CDs which had been widely criticized for their lack of clarity and dynamism, <i><a href="/wiki/Mojo_(magazine)" title="Mojo (magazine)">Mojo</a></i>'s Danny Eccleston wrote, "the remastered vocals are purer, more natural-sounding and give the illusion of sitting slightly higher in the mix."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> A second collection, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_in_Mono&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles in Mono (page does not exist)">The Beatles in Mono</a></i>, included remastered versions of every Beatles album released in true mono along with the original 1965 stereo mixes of <i>Help!</i> and <i>Rubber Soul</i> (which George Martin had remixed for the 1987 editions).<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles:_Rock_Band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles: Rock Band (page does not exist)">The Beatles: Rock Band</a></i>, a music video game in the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rock_Band&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rock Band (page does not exist)">Rock Band</a></i> series, was released the same day.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In December 2009, the band's catalogue was officially released in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_Lossless_Audio_Codec&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free Lossless Audio Codec (page does not exist)">FLAC</a> and MP3 format in <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_Stereo_Box_Set&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles Stereo Box Set (page does not exist)">a limited edition of 30,000 USB flash drives</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="2010s">2010s</span></h4>
<p>Owing to a long running royalty disagreement, the Beatles were among the last major artists to sign deals with online music services.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Residual disagreement emanating from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Apple_Corps_v_Apple_Computer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Apple Corps v Apple Computer (page does not exist)">Apple Corps' dispute with Apple, Inc.</a>, <a href="/wiki/ITunes" title="ITunes">iTunes</a>' owners, over the use of the name "Apple" was also partly responsible for the delay, although in 2008, McCartney stated that the main obstacle to making the Beatles' catalogue available online was that EMI "want[s] something we're not prepared to give them."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 2010, the official canon of thirteen Beatles studio albums, <i>Past Masters</i>, and the <i>Red</i> and <i>Blue</i> greatest-hits albums were made available on iTunes.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 2012, EMI's recorded music operations were sold to <a href="/wiki/Universal_Music_Group" title="Universal Music Group">Universal Music Group</a>. In order for Universal Music to acquire EMI, the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antitrust&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antitrust (page does not exist)">antitrust</a> reasons forced EMI to spin off assets including Parlophone. EMI was allowed to keep the Beatles' recorded music catalogue which is expected to be managed in the UK by a newly formed Capitol Records unit of Universal Music.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Also in 2012, EMI reissued the entire original Beatles album catalogue on vinyl available either individually or as a box set.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>December 2013 saw the release of another 59 Beatles recordings on iTunes. The set, titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles_Bootleg_Recordings_1963&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles Bootleg Recordings 1963 (page does not exist)">The Beatles Bootleg Recordings 1963</a></i>, had the opportunity to gain a 70-year copyright extension conditional on them being published at least once before the end of 2013. Apple Records released the songs on 17 December to prevent them from going into the public domain and had them taken down from iTunes later that same day. Fan reactions to the release were mixed with one blogger saying "the hardcore Beatles collectors who are trying to obtain everything will already have these."<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Musical_style_and_development">Musical style and development</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>In <i>Icons of Rock: An Encyclopedia of the Legends Who Changed Music Forever</i>, Scott Schinder and Andy Schwartz describe the Beatles' musical evolution:
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Blockquote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Blockquote (page does not exist)">Template:Blockquote</a>
</p><p>In <i>The Beatles as Musicians</i>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walter_Everett_(musicologist)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walter Everett (musicologist) (page does not exist)">Walter Everett</a> describes Lennon and McCartney's contrasting motivations and approaches to composition: "McCartney may be said to have constantly developed—as a means to entertain—a focused musical talent with an ear for counterpoint and other aspects of craft in the demonstration of a universally agreed-upon common language that he did much to enrich. Conversely, Lennon's mature music is best appreciated as the daring product of a largely unconscious, searching but undisciplined artistic sensibility."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Musicology" title="Musicology">Musicologist</a> and author <a href="/wiki/Ian_MacDonald" title="Ian MacDonald">Ian MacDonald</a> describes McCartney as "a natural melodist—a creator of tunes capable of existing apart from their harmony". His melody lines are characterized as primarily "vertical", employing wide, <a href="/wiki/Consonance_and_dissonance" title="Consonance and dissonance">consonant</a> intervals which express his "extrovert energy and optimism". Conversely, Lennon's "sedentary, ironic personality" is reflected in a "horizontal" approach featuring minimal, dissonant intervals and repetitive melodies which rely on their harmonic accompaniment for interest: "Basically a realist, he instinctively kept his melodies close to the rhythms and cadences of speech, colouring his lyrics with bluesy tone and harmony rather than creating tunes that made striking shapes of their own."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> MacDonald praises Harrison's lead guitar work for the role his "characterful lines and textural colourings" play in supporting Lennon and McCartney's parts, and describes Starr as "the father of modern pop/rock drumming".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Influences">Influences</span></h3>
<p>Their earliest influences include <a href="/wiki/Elvis_Presley" title="Elvis Presley">Elvis Presley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carl_Perkins" title="Carl Perkins">Carl Perkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Little_Richard" title="Little Richard">Little Richard</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Berry" title="Chuck Berry">Chuck Berry</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> During the Beatles' co-residency with Little Richard at the <a href="/wiki/Star-Club" title="Star-Club">Star-Club</a> in Hamburg, from April to May 1962, he advised them on the proper technique for performing his songs.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Of Presley, Lennon said, "Nothing really affected me until I heard Elvis. If there hadn't been Elvis, there would not have been the Beatles."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Other early influences include Buddy Holly, <a href="/wiki/Eddie_Cochran" title="Eddie Cochran">Eddie Cochran</a>, Roy Orbison<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and the Everly Brothers.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They continued to absorb influences long after their initial success, often finding new musical and lyrical avenues by listening to their contemporaries, including Bob Dylan, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Zappa" title="Frank Zappa">Frank Zappa</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Lovin%27_Spoonful" title="The Lovin' Spoonful">the Lovin' Spoonful</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Byrds" title="The Byrds">the Byrds</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Beach_Boys" title="The Beach Boys">the Beach Boys</a>, whose 1966 album <i><a href="/wiki/Pet_Sounds" title="Pet Sounds">Pet Sounds</a></i> amazed and inspired McCartney.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin stated, "Without <i>Pet Sounds</i>, <i>Sgt. Pepper</i> wouldn't have happened&#160;...<i>Pepper</i> was an attempt to equal <i>Pet Sounds</i>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> <a href="/wiki/Ravi_Shankar" title="Ravi Shankar">Ravi Shankar</a>, with whom Harrison studied for six weeks in India in late 1966, had a significant effect on his musical development during the band's later years.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genres">Genres</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Guitarras_de_McCartney_y_Harrison.jpg" title="File:Guitarras de McCartney y Harrison.jpg">File:Guitarras de McCartney y Harrison.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <a href="/w/index.php?title=H%C3%B6fner_500/1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Höfner 500/1 (page does not exist)">Höfner "violin" bass guitar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gretsch" title="Gretsch">Gretsch Country Gentleman guitar</a>, models played by McCartney and Harrison, respectively; the <a href="/wiki/Vox_(musical_equipment)" title="Vox (musical equipment)">Vox AC30</a> amplifier behind them is the model the Beatles used during performances in the early 1960s</div></div></div>
<p>Originating as a skiffle group, the Beatles quickly embraced 1950s rock and roll, and their repertoire ultimately expanded to include a broad variety of pop music.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Reflecting the range of styles they explored, Lennon said of <i>Beatles for Sale</i>, "You could call our new one a Beatles country-and-western LP",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> while Gould credits <i>Rubber Soul</i> as "the instrument by which legions of folk-music enthusiasts were coaxed into the camp of pop."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The 1965 song "Yesterday" makes prominent use of a string quartet; while it was not the first pop record to employ strings, it marked the group's first recorded use of classical music elements. Gould observes, "The more traditional sound of strings allowed for a fresh appreciation of their talent as composers by listeners who were otherwise allergic to the din of drums and electric guitars."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They continued to experiment with string arrangements to various effect: <i>Sgt. Pepper</i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:%27&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:' (page does not exist)">Template:'s</a> "<a href="/wiki/She%27s_Leaving_Home" title="She's Leaving Home">She's Leaving Home</a>", for instance, is "cast in the <span lang="en-US">mold</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> of a sentimental Victorian ballad," wrote Gould, "its words and music filled with the clichés of musical melodrama."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>The band's stylistic range expanded in another direction in 1966 with the B-side to the "<a href="/wiki/Paperback_Writer" title="Paperback Writer">Paperback Writer</a>" single: "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rain_(The_Beatles_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rain (The Beatles song) (page does not exist)">Rain</a>", described by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martin_C._Strong&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martin C. Strong (page does not exist)">Martin Strong</a> as "the first overtly psychedelic Beatles record".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Psychedelic_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Psychedelic music (page does not exist)">psychedelic</a> numbers followed, such as "<a href="/wiki/Tomorrow_Never_Knows" title="Tomorrow Never Knows">Tomorrow Never Knows</a>" (recorded before "Rain"), "Strawberry Fields Forever", "<a href="/wiki/Lucy_in_the_Sky_with_Diamonds" title="Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds">Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/I_Am_the_Walrus" title="I Am the Walrus">I Am the Walrus</a>". The influence of <a href="/wiki/Indian_classical_music" title="Indian classical music">Indian classical music</a> was evident in Harrison's "<a href="/wiki/The_Inner_Light_(song)" title="The Inner Light (song)">The Inner Light</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Love_You_To" title="Love You To">Love You To</a>" and "Within You Without You"; Gould describes the latter two as attempts "to replicate the <a href="/wiki/Raga" title="Raga">raga</a> form in miniature".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Innovation was the most striking feature of their creative evolution, according to music historian and pianist Michael Campbell: "'<a href="/wiki/A_Day_in_the_Life" title="A Day in the Life">A Day in the Life</a>' encapsulates the art and achievement of the Beatles as well as any single track can. It highlights key features of their music: the sound imagination, the persistence of tuneful melody, and the close coordination between words and music. It represents a new category of song—more sophisticated than pop&#160;... and uniquely innovative. There literally had never before been a song—classical or vernacular—that had blended so many disparate elements so imaginatively."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Philosophy professor Bruce Ellis Benson agrees: "the Beatles&#160;... give us a wonderful example of how such far-ranging influences as Celtic music, rhythm and blues, and country and western could be put together in a new way."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Author Dominic Pedler describes the way they crossed musical styles: "Far from moving sequentially from one genre to another (as is sometimes conveniently suggested) the group maintained <i>in parallel</i> their mastery of the traditional, catchy chart hit while simultaneously forging rock and dabbling with a wide range of peripheral influences from Country to vaudeville. One of these threads was their take on folk music, which would form such essential groundwork for their later collisions with Indian music and philosophy."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> As the personal relationships between the band members grew increasingly strained, their individual tastes became more apparent.
