The minimalistic cover artwork for the <i>White Album</i> contrasted with the complexity and diversity of its music, which encompassed Lennon's "<a href="/wiki/Revolution_9" title="Revolution 9">Revolution 9</a>", whose <a href="/wiki/Musique_concr%C3%A8te" title="Musique concrète">musique concrète</a> approach was influenced by Yoko Ono; Starr's <a href="/wiki/Country_music" title="Country music">country</a> song "<a href="/wiki/Don%27t_Pass_Me_By" title="Don't Pass Me By">Don't Pass Me By</a>"; Harrison's <a href="/wiki/Rock_ballad" title="Rock ballad" class="mw-redirect">rock ballad</a> "<a href="/wiki/While_My_Guitar_Gently_Weeps" title="While My Guitar Gently Weeps">While My Guitar Gently Weeps</a>"; and the "<a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music#Origins:_late_1960s_and_early_1970s" title="Heavy metal music">proto-metal</a> roar" of McCartney's "<a href="/wiki/Helter_Skelter_(song)" title="Helter Skelter (song)">Helter Skelter</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Contribution_of_George_Martin">Contribution of George Martin</span></h3>
<p>George Martin's close involvement in his role as producer made him one of the leading candidates for the informal title of the "<a href="/wiki/Fifth_Beatle" title="Fifth Beatle">fifth Beatle</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> He applied his classical musical training in various ways, and functioned as "an informal music teacher" to the progressing songwriters, wrote Gould.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin suggested to a sceptical McCartney that the arrangement of "Yesterday" should feature a string quartet accompaniment, thereby introducing the Beatles to a "hitherto unsuspected world of classical instrumental colour", in MacDonald's description.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their creative development was also facilitated by Martin's willingness to experiment in response to their suggestions, such as adding "something <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baroque_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baroque music (page does not exist)">baroque</a>" to a particular recording.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In addition to scoring orchestral arrangements for recordings, Martin often performed on them, playing instruments including piano, organ and <a href="/wiki/Brass_instrument" title="Brass instrument">brass</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Collaborating with Lennon and McCartney required Martin to adapt to their different approaches to songwriting and recording. MacDonald comments, "while [he] worked more naturally with the conventionally articulate McCartney, the challenge of catering to Lennon's intuitive approach generally spurred him to his more original arrangements, of which '<a href="/wiki/Being_for_the_Benefit_of_Mr._Kite!" title="Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!">Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!</a>' is an outstanding example."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Martin said of the two composers' distinct songwriting styles and his own stabilizing influence,
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Blockquote&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Blockquote (page does not exist)">Template:Blockquote</a>
</p><p>Harrison echoed Martin's description of his stabilizing role: "I think we just grew through those years together, him as the straight man and us as the loonies; but he was always there for us to interpret our madness—we used to be slightly avant-garde on certain days of the week, and he would be there as the anchor person, to communicate that through the engineers and on to the tape."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="In_the_studio">In the studio</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Making innovative use of technology while expanding the possibilities of recorded music, the Beatles urged experimentation by Martin and his recording engineers. Seeking ways to put chance occurrences to creative use, accidental guitar feedback, a resonating glass bottle, a tape loaded the wrong way round so that it played backwards—any of these might be incorporated into their music.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Their desire to create new sounds on every new recording, combined with Martin's arranging abilities and the studio expertise of EMI staff engineers <a href="/wiki/Norman_Smith_(record_producer)" title="Norman Smith (record producer)">Norman Smith</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ken_Townsend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ken Townsend (page does not exist)">Ken Townsend</a>, and Emerick, all contributed significantly to their records from <i>Rubber Soul</i> and, especially, <i>Revolver</i> forward.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Along with innovative studio techniques such as <a href="/wiki/Audio_signal_processing" title="Audio signal processing">sound effects</a>, unconventional microphone placements, <a href="/wiki/Tape_loop" title="Tape loop">tape loops</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Double_tracking&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Double tracking (page does not exist)">double tracking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vari-speed" title="Vari-speed" class="mw-redirect">vari-speed</a> recording, the Beatles augmented their songs with instruments that were unconventional in rock music at the time. These included string and brass ensembles as well as Indian instruments such as the <a href="/wiki/Sitar" title="Sitar">sitar</a> in "<a href="/wiki/Norwegian_Wood_(This_Bird_Has_Flown)" title="Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)">Norwegian Wood (This Bird Has Flown)</a>" and the <a href="/wiki/Swarmandal" title="Swarmandal">swarmandal</a> in "Strawberry Fields Forever".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They also used early electronic instruments such as the <a href="/wiki/Mellotron" title="Mellotron">Mellotron</a>, with which McCartney supplied the flute voices on the "Strawberry Fields" intro,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Clavioline" title="Clavioline">clavioline</a>, an electronic keyboard that created the unusual oboe-like sound on "<a href="/wiki/Baby,_You%27re_a_Rich_Man" title="Baby, You're a Rich Man">Baby, You're a Rich Man</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Beatles_on_Green_Hill_in_Almaty,_Kazakhstan.jpg" title="File:The Beatles on Green Hill in Almaty, Kazakhstan.jpg">File:The Beatles on Green Hill in Almaty, Kazakhstan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Statue in <a href="/wiki/Almaty" title="Almaty">Almaty</a>, Kazakhstan</div></div></div>
<p>Former <i>Rolling Stone</i> associate editor Robert Greenfield compared the Beatles to <a href="/wiki/Pablo_Picasso" title="Pablo Picasso">Picasso</a>, as "artists who broke through the constraints of their time period to come up with something that was unique and original&#160;... [I]n the form of popular music, no one will ever be more revolutionary, more creative and more distinctive".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They not only sparked the British Invasion of the US,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> they became a globally influential phenomenon as well.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refn (page does not exist)">Template:Refn</a>
</p><p>Their musical innovations and commercial success inspired musicians worldwide.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Many artists have acknowledged the Beatles' influence and enjoyed chart success with <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_artists_who_have_covered_The_Beatles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of artists who have covered The Beatles (page does not exist)">covers of their songs</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> On radio, their arrival marked the beginning of a new era; in 1968 the programme director of New York's <a href="/wiki/WABC_(AM)" title="WABC (AM)">WABC</a> radio station forbid his DJs from playing any "pre-Beatles" music.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They helped to redefine the album as something more than just a few hits padded out with "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Filler_(media)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Filler (media) (page does not exist)">filler</a>",<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and they were primary innovators of the modern music video.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The Shea Stadium show with which they opened their <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Beatles%27_1965_US_tour&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Beatles' 1965 US tour (page does not exist)">1965 North American tour</a> attracted an estimated 55,600 people,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> then the largest audience in concert history; Spitz describes the event as a "major breakthrough&#160;... a giant step toward reshaping the concert business."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Emulation of their clothing and especially their hairstyles, which became a mark of rebellion, had a global impact on fashion, wrote Gould.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>According to Gould, the Beatles changed the way people listened to popular music and experienced its role in their lives. From what began as the Beatlemania fad, the group's popularity grew into what was seen as an embodiment of sociocultural movements of the decade. As icons of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Counterculture_of_the_1960s&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Counterculture of the 1960s (page does not exist)">1960s counterculture</a>, Gould continues, they became a catalyst for <a href="/wiki/Bohemianism" title="Bohemianism">bohemianism</a> and activism in various social and political arenas, fuelling movements such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Feminist_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Feminist movement (page does not exist)">women's liberation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gay_liberation" title="Gay liberation">gay liberation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Environmental_movement" title="Environmental movement">environmentalism</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> According to Peter Lavezzoli, after the "more popular than Jesus" controversy in 1966, the Beatles felt considerable pressure to say the right things and "began a concerted effort to spread a message of wisdom and higher consciousness."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards_and_achievements">Awards and achievements</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>In 1965, Queen <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Elizabeth II</a> appointed Lennon, McCartney, Harrison and Starr <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Order of the British Empire">Members of the Order of the British Empire (MBE)</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The film <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Let_It_Be_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Let It Be (film) (page does not exist)">Let It Be</a></i> (1970) won the 1971 Academy Award for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_Award_for_Best_Music_(Scoring)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy Award for Best Music (Scoring) (page does not exist)">Best Original Song Score</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The recipients of 7 Grammy Awards<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and 15 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ivor_Novello_Awards&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ivor Novello Awards (page does not exist)">Ivor Novello Awards</a>,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> the Beatles have been awarded 6 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Diamond albums</a>, as well as 24 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Multi-Platinum albums</a>, 39 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Platinum albums</a> and 45 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Gold albums</a> in the United States.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In the UK, the Beatles have 4 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Multi-Platinum albums</a>, 4 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Platinum albums</a>, 8 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Gold albums</a> and 1 <a href="/wiki/Music_recording_sales_certification" title="Music recording sales certification">Silver album</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They were inducted into the <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_Roll_Hall_of_Fame" title="Rock and Roll Hall of Fame">Rock and Roll Hall of Fame</a> in 1988.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">best-selling band</a> in history, the Beatles have sold between 600 million<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> and (at EMI estimates) over one billion units worldwide.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They have had more number one albums on the British charts, 15,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and sold more singles in the UK, 21.9 million, than any other act.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 2004, <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> ranked the Beatles as the best artist of all time.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They ranked number one in <i>Billboard</i> magazine's list of the all-time most successful <a href="/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100" title="Billboard Hot 100">Hot 100</a> artists, released in 2008 to celebrate the US singles chart's fiftieth anniversary.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> As of 2012, they hold the record for most number one hits on the Hot 100 chart with 20.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recording_Industry_Association_of_America&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recording Industry Association of America (page does not exist)">Recording Industry Association of America</a> certifies that the Beatles have sold 177 million units in the US, more than any other artist.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> They were collectively included in <i>Time</i> magazine's compilation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_100:_The_Most_Important_People_of_the_Century&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time 100: The Most Important People of the Century (page does not exist)">the 20th century's 100 most influential people</a>.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 2014, they received the <a href="/wiki/Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award" title="Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award">Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discography">Discography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Original_UK_LPs">Original UK LPs</span></h3>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Please_Please_Me" title="Please Please Me">Please Please Me</a></i> (1963)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/With_the_Beatles" title="With the Beatles">With the Beatles</a></i> (1963)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/A_Hard_Day%27s_Night_(album)" title="A Hard Day's Night (album)">A Hard Day's Night</a></i> (1964)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Beatles_for_Sale" title="Beatles for Sale">Beatles for Sale</a></i> (1964)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Help!_(album)" title="Help! (album)">Help!</a></i> (1965)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Rubber_Soul" title="Rubber Soul">Rubber Soul</a></i> (1965)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Revolver_(Beatles_album)" title="Revolver (Beatles album)">Revolver</a></i> (1966)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Sgt._Pepper%27s_Lonely_Hearts_Club_Band" title="Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band">Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band</a></i> (1967)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles_(album)" title="The Beatles (album)">The Beatles</a></i> (1968)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Yellow_Submarine_(album)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Yellow Submarine (album) (page does not exist)">Yellow Submarine</a></i> (1969)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Abbey_Road" title="Abbey Road">Abbey Road</a></i> (1969)
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/wiki/Let_It_Be" title="Let It Be">Let It Be</a></i> (1970)
</li>
</ul>
<p>See also the EP <i><a href="/wiki/Long_Tall_Sally_(EP)" title="Long Tall Sally (EP)">Long Tall Sally</a></i> (1964) and the double-EP <i><a href="/wiki/Magical_Mystery_Tour" title="Magical Mystery Tour">Magical Mystery Tour</a></i> (1967), which contain music not released on the original UK LPs. When the above albums were reissued on CDs, the American <i>Magical Mystery Tour</i> album was issued on CD globally and the double CD compilation set <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Past_Masters&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Past Masters (page does not exist)">Past Masters</a></i> was issued so every Beatle track commercially released would be available on CD.
</p>
<dl>
<dt>See also</dt>
<dd>
</dd>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/John_Lennon_discography" title="John Lennon discography">John Lennon discography</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Paul_McCartney_discography" title="Paul McCartney discography">Paul McCartney discography</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/George_Harrison_discography" title="George Harrison discography">George Harrison discography</a>
</li>

</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Collaborations_between_ex-Beatles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Collaborations between ex-Beatles (page does not exist)">Collaborations between ex-Beatles</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Song_catalogue">Song catalogue</span></h2>
<p>Through 1969, the Beatles' catalogue was published almost exclusively by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Northern_Songs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Northern Songs (page does not exist)">Northern Songs Ltd.</a>, a company formed in February 1963 by music publisher <a href="/wiki/Dick_James" title="Dick James">Dick James</a> specifically for Lennon and McCartney, though it later acquired songs by other artists. The company was organized with James and his partner, Emmanuel Silver, owning a controlling interest, variously described as 51% or 50% plus one share. McCartney had 20%. Reports again vary concerning Lennon's portion—19 or 20%—and Brian Epstein's—9 or 10%—which he received in lieu of a 25% band management fee.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 1965, the company went public. Five million shares were created, of which the original principals retained 3.75 million. James and Silver each received 937,500 shares (18.75% of 5 million); Lennon and McCartney each received 750,000 shares (15%); and Epstein's management company NEMS Enterprises received 375,000 shares (7.5%). Of the 1.25 million shares put up for sale, Harrison and Starr each acquired 40,000.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> At the time of the stock offering, Lennon and McCartney renewed their three-year publishing contracts, binding them to Northern Songs until 1973.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Harrison created <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harrisongs&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harrisongs (page does not exist)">Harrisongs</a> to represent his Beatles compositions, but signed a three-year contract with Northern Songs that gave it the copyright to his work through March 1968, which included "<a href="/wiki/Taxman" title="Taxman">Taxman</a>" and "Within You Without You".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The songs on which Starr received co-writing credit before 1968, such as "<a href="/w/index.php?title=What_Goes_On_(The_Beatles_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="What Goes On (The Beatles song) (page does not exist)">What Goes On</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Flying_(The_Beatles_song)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Flying (The Beatles song) (page does not exist)">Flying</a>", were also Northern Songs copyrights.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Harrison did not renew his contract with Northern Songs when it ended, signing instead with <a href="/wiki/Apple_Corps" title="Apple Corps">Apple Publishing</a> while retaining the copyright to his work from that point forward. Harrisongs thus owns the rights to his later Beatles songs such as "<a href="/wiki/While_My_Guitar_Gently_Weeps" title="While My Guitar Gently Weeps">While My Guitar Gently Weeps</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Something" title="Something">Something</a>". That year, as well, Starr created <a href="/w/index.php?title=Startling_Music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Startling Music (page does not exist)">Startling Music</a>, which holds the rights to his Beatles compositions, "Don't Pass Me By" and "<a href="/wiki/Octopus%27s_Garden" title="Octopus's Garden">Octopus's Garden</a>".<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In March 1969, James arranged to sell his and his partner's shares of Northern Songs to the British broadcasting company <a href="/wiki/Associated_Television" title="Associated Television">Associated Television</a> (ATV), founded by impresario <a href="/wiki/Lew_Grade" title="Lew Grade">Lew Grade</a>, without first informing the Beatles. The band then made a bid to gain controlling interest by attempting to work out a deal with a consortium of London brokerage firms that had accumulated a 14% holding.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> The deal collapsed over the objections of Lennon, who declared, "I'm sick of being fucked about by men in suits sitting on their fat arses in the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City</a>."<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> By the end of May, ATV had acquired a majority stake in Northern Songs, controlling nearly the entire Lennon–McCartney catalog, as well as any future material until 1973.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In frustration, Lennon and McCartney sold their shares to ATV in late October 1969.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>In 1981, financial losses by ATV's parent company ACC led it to attempt to sell its music division. According to authors Brian Southall and Rupert Perry, Grade contacted McCartney, offering ATV Music and Northern Songs for $30 million.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> According to an account McCartney gave in 1995, he met with Grade and explained he was interested solely in the Northern Songs catalog, if Grade were ever willing to "separate off" that portion of ATV Music. Soon after, Grade offered to sell him Northern Songs for £20 million, giving the ex-Beatle "a week or so" to decide. By McCartney's account, he and Ono countered with a £5 million bid that was rejected.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> According to reports at the time, Grade refused to separate Northern Songs, and turned down an offer of £21–£25 million from McCartney and Ono for ATV Music. In 1982 ACC as a whole was sold to Australian business magnate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Holmes_%C3%A0_Court&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Holmes à Court (page does not exist)">Robert Holmes à Court</a> for £60 million.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Three years later, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Jackson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Jackson (page does not exist)">Michael Jackson</a> purchased ATV for a reported $47.5 million. The acquisition gave him control over the publishing rights to more than 200 Beatles songs, as well as 40,000 other copyrights.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> In 1995, in a deal that earned him a reported $110 million, Jackson merged his music publishing business with <a href="/wiki/Sony" title="Sony">Sony</a>, creating a new company, <a href="/wiki/Sony/ATV_Music_Publishing" title="Sony/ATV Music Publishing">Sony/ATV Music Publishing</a>, in which he held a 50% stake. The merger made the new company, then valued at over half a billion dollars, the third largest music publisher in the world.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p><p>Despite the lack of publishing rights to most of their songs, Lennon's estate and McCartney continue to receive their respective shares of the writers' royalties, which together are 33⅓% of total commercial proceeds in the US and which vary elsewhere around the world between 50 and 55%.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> Two of Lennon and McCartney's earliest songs—"Love Me Do" and "P.S. I Love You"—were published by an EMI subsidiary, Ardmore &amp; Beechwood, before they signed with James. McCartney acquired their publishing rights from Ardmore in the mid-1980s,<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a> and they are the only two Beatles songs owned by McCartney's company MPL Communications.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sfn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sfn (page does not exist)">Template:Sfn</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>

<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refend (page does not exist)">Template:Refend</a>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refbegin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refbegin (page does not exist)">Template:Refbegin</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>

</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
<li><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cite_book&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cite book (page does not exist)">Template:Cite book</a>
</li>
